title: Lauda Air Aircraft Lease Scandal
description:
The Lauda Air scandal involves significant allegations of corruption and procedural irregularities within the state-owned Royal Nepal Airlines Corporation (RNAC), now Nepal Airlines Corporation, concerning the lease of a Boeing 767 aircraft from Austria's Lauda Air in 2000-2001. The core of the controversy was the decision to lease the aircraft through direct negotiation instead of a competitive global tender, which was contrary to directives from the parliamentary Public Accounts Committee (PAC) and the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA).

The CIAA subsequently investigated the deal and filed a corruption case on May 24, 2001, alleging embezzlement amounting to NPR 389.7 million. The accused included the then-Minister for Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation, Tarini Datta Chataut, RNAC's Executive Chairman Hari Bhakta Shrestha, and several board members and officials, as well as two officials from Lauda Air.

Key issues raised by investigators and critics included:

  • Procedural Bypass: The procurement process deliberately avoided a transparent, competitive bidding process, raising suspicions of foul play.
  • Inflated Costs: The official lease rate of $3,350 per flying hour was allegedly a fraction of the real cost, which was believed to exceed $5,000 per hour when including hidden charges for spares, crew, and other services.
  • Lack of Necessity: Critics, including RNAC's own employee unions, argued that the airline's existing fleet was underutilized and there was no operational or financial justification for leasing a fourth aircraft. The airline, reportedly profitable before the lease, began incurring heavy monthly losses afterward.
  • Political Involvement: The scandal had major political repercussions, leading to the resignation of Tourism Minister Chataut and contributing to the resignation of then-Prime Minister Girija Prasad Koirala, whose cabinet had approved the deal.

On August 13, 2007, the Special Court acquitted all accused, citing a lack of sufficient evidence. The CIAA appealed this verdict at the Supreme Court. On May 25, 2018, a division bench of the Supreme Court delivered a split verdict, with one justice finding two former RNAC officials guilty and the other upholding the acquittal. Due to the split decision, the case was referred to a full bench, where it has remained pending for years, subject to numerous postponements.
unverified_info:
There are several unconfirmed details and conflicting reports related to the case:

  • Total Financial Loss: While the CIAA's official claim was for NPR 389.7 million, other estimates of the total loss to RNAC varied widely. One report cited a figure as high as NPR 2 billion, while another calculated the loss at approximately NPR 335 million. RNAC employees claimed the lease created an extra financial burden of nearly NPR 110 million per month.
  • Alleged Commissions: Media reports at the time alleged that a commission of $400 per flying hour was built into the deal, which would have totaled approximately NPR 160 million over the 18-month lease term. This amount was purportedly to be divided among a 'political fund', the Lauda Air agent in Nepal, and RNAC officials.
  • Aircraft Ownership: A PAC investigation reportedly found that the aircraft did not belong to Lauda Air but to a separate, unnamed Hong Kong-based company, a detail not mentioned in the lease agreement.
  • Name Discrepancy: One of the accused, the RNAC Marketing Director, is referred to as both Ramraj Upadhyaya and Raja Ram Upadhyaya in different documents.
key_allegations: Embezzlement of NPR 389.7 million from state funds.
Leasing an aircraft through direct negotiation, bypassing the required competitive tender process.
Abuse of authority by public officials to cause financial loss to Royal Nepal Airlines Corporation.
Leasing an aircraft that was not operationally necessary, leading to significant financial losses.
Ignoring directives from the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) and the Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA).
related_entities: Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA)
Public Accounts Committee (PAC), Parliament of Nepal

timeline.title: RNAC Board Approves Lease
timeline.description: The board of directors of the Royal Nepal Airlines Corporation (RNAC) decides to lease a Boeing 767 aircraft from Lauda Air through direct negotiation, bypassing a global tender.

timeline.title: Tourism Minister Resigns
timeline.description: Tarini Datta Chataut resigns from his post as Minister of Tourism and Civil Aviation to 'pave the way for the investigation' into the scandal.

timeline.title: CIAA Files Corruption Case
timeline.description: The Commission for the Investigation of Abuse of Authority (CIAA) files a corruption case at the Patan Appellate Court against 10 individuals, alleging embezzlement of NPR 389.7 million.

timeline.title: Special Court Acquits All Accused
timeline.description: The Special Court, comprising judges Bhoopdhoj Adhikary, Komal Nath Sharma, and Cholendra S.J.B. Rana, acquits all 10 accused, citing a lack of sufficient evidence.

timeline.title: Supreme Court Delivers Split Verdict
timeline.description: A division bench of the Supreme Court, with Justices Ishwor Prasad Khatiwada and Sharada Prasad Ghimire, delivers a split verdict. Justice Khatiwada found two officials guilty, while Justice Ghimire upheld the acquittal. The case is referred to a full bench.
